questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive male with a history of disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection presents for a routine check-up. He is compliant with antiretroviral therapy (ART) and has a CD4+ count of 46 cells/μL. Which prophylactic therapy is recommended in this patient to prevent Mycobacterium avium complex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Clarithromycin + ethambutol

 

Explanation:

  • Clarithromycin + ethambutol is used to prevent MAC in patients with a previous MAC infection, especially if they have a low CD4+ count (<50 cells/μL).
  • Alternatively, Azithromycin + Ethambutol can also be used as prevention.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with  triple vessel disease presents with a persistent cough, fever, and shortness of breath. On admission he has respiratory rate 26 /minute and an sp02 92% on room air. His RT-PCR for SARS-COV2 is positive. What is the preferred oxygen delivery device for this patient?

choices.text: Non invasive ventilation with tight fitting face mask
Nasal cannula and flow rate of 6L/min

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Non-rebreathing face mask

 

Explanation:

The clinical scenario with a positive RT-PCR test suggests a diagnosis of Moderate COVID-19. In this case, a non-rebreathing face mask is the preferred oxygen delivery device. If needed then we can upgade to NIV or high flow nasal cannula.  

Step up oxygen therapy would be as follows: 

1. Non rebreather mask and flow rate of O2: 12-15L/min 

2. Non invasive ventilation using a tight fitting face mask 

3. High flow nasal cannula 

4. Tracheostomy and Positive pressure ventilation

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with obesity and hypertension presents with a cough, fever  and shortness of breath for the past four days. Her SpO2 is 90% on room air and her respiratory rate is 34/min. Her RT-PCR for SARS COV2 is positive. Which of the following is correct about laboratory findings seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Elevated NLR

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and positive RT-PCR result confirm the diagnosis of COVID-19, characterised by an elevated neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR).

 

Laboratory findings of COVID-19

Elevated Parameters

Reduced parameters
  • Inflammatory markers (interleukin 6, tumour necrosis factor α, ferritin, C-reactive protein) (Option B)
  • NLR (neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio) >6 (Option D)
  • Prothrombin time
  • D-dimer assay (Option A)
  • Pro-BNP and troponin I
  • Liver enzymes and lactate dehydrogenase
  • Creatine phosphokinase
  • Platelet count (thrombocytopenia) (Option C)
  • TLC or Total lymphocyte count (lymphopenia)
  • Erythrocyte count (anemia)
  • Pulmonary function test

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of asthma presents with a persistent cough, fever, and shortness of breath that started three days ago after attending a family gathering. His examination shows a SpO2 of 92% on room air and a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, with the accompanying X-ray. What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) RT-PCR

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of persistent cough, fever, shortness of breath, and recent exposure to a family gathering raise suspicion of a viral respiratory infection, particularly COVID-19.
  • RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction) is the standard method for confirming the diagnosis of COVID-19 due to its high sensitivity and specificity.

Investigations of COVID-19:

  • Lab investigations
    • RT-PCR or Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction (investigation of choice)
      • A nucleic acid amplification testing of respiratory tract secretions.
      • Sample: Nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal swabs (neck extended).
    • Rapid Antigen Test (RAT) (Option D ruled out): Used for large-scale testing.
    • Alarm markers: Elevated values of D-Dimer, CRP (C-reactive protein) (Option B ruled out), LDH, IL-6, Ferritin, Troponin I, Pro-BNP.
    • CBC (complete blood count):
      • Lymphopenia, thrombocytopenia
      • NLR (neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio) > 6
  • Radiological features
    • X-ray chest: Bilateral multiple ground glass opacities (commonly in the lower and middle lungs).
    • HRCT (high-resolution computed tomography) (Option A ruled out)
      • Ground glass opacities (towards the periphery) and reticular patterns give the characteristic “crazy pavement pattern.”
      • Reverse Halo sign: A focal, round area of ground-glass opacity encircled by a nearly complete ring of consolidation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive man with a CD4 count of 80 cells/mm³ presents with chronic watery diarrhea and significant weight loss. Stool examination reveals oval-shaped oocysts measuring 20–30 microns, which appear pink to red on modified Kinyoun stain, showing a characteristic sporoblast. Which of the following is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) TMP-SMX

Explanation:

  • Cystoisospora belli is a coccidian parasite that causes prolonged, watery diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals, especially AIDS patients with CD4 < 100.

  • Oocysts are large (20–30 microns), oval, and demonstrate acid-fast positivity (pink to red) on modified Kinyoun stain.

  • TMP-SMX is the first-line treatment and also used for secondary prophylaxis.

  • Metronidazole is not effective against coccidia.

  • Nitazoxanide is used in Cryptosporidiosis, not preferred here.

  • Albendazole has no role against Cystoisospora.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with AIDS  with CD4 count  of 74 cells/μL presents with acute onset of odynophagia and retrosternal chest pain. Upper GI endoscopy reveals well-circumscribed, "volcano-like" ulcers in the mid-esophagus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Herpes esophagitis 

 

Explanation:

  • CMV esophagitis is characterized by deep, linear ulcers in the distal esophagus ( serpignious ulcers ) and typically occurs at CD4 < 100 cells/μL.

  • HSV esophagitis shows multiple small, punched-out, volcano-like ulcers in the mid-esophagus.

  • Candida esophagitis presents with white, plaque-like lesions and is often accompanied by oral thrush.

  • Drug-induced esophagitis usually causes localized ulceration without systemic immunosuppression and doesn’t typically occur in distal esophagus in this pattern.

questions.text: A medical intern sustains a needle-stick injury from a known HIV-positive patient. What is the ideal time frame to initiate post-exposure prophylaxis for maximum efficacy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Within 2 hours 

 

Explanation:

Post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV should be started as early as possible preferably within 2 hours. It is not effective after 72 hours. Drugs used are tenofovir, lamivudine and dolutregavir for 4 weeks. Waiting for test results or seroconversion is incorrect and delays treatment.

questions.text: You have started fluconazole for secondary prevention of cryptococcus neoformans meningitis. Which of the following is correct statement about it?

choices.text: Continue till CD4 count > 100 cells for 3 months and HIV RNA < 500 copies/ ml
Continue till CD4 count > 200 cells for 3 months and HIV RNA < 500 copies/ ml
Continue till CD4 count > 100 cells for 3 months and HIV RNA < 5000 copies/ ml
Continue till CD4 count > 200 cells and HIV RNA < 5000 copies/ ml

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: CD4 count > 100 cells/cu.mm for 3 months and HIV RNA < 5000 copies/ ml

 

Secondary prevention of cryptococcal meningitis is Fluconazole 200 mg once per day till CD4 count is > 100 cells for 3 months and HIV RNA viral load is less than 500 copies / ml. Treatment is with Liposomal amphotericin B with 5 Flucytosine till CSF is cleared or atleast 2 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is effective against both HIV and hepatitis B?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tenofovir

 

Explanation:

Tenofovir (in both its formulations, tenofovir disoproxil fumarate [TDF] or tenofovir alafenamide [TAF]) is effective against both HIV and HBV.

 

HIV uses reverse transcriptase to convert its RNA into proviral DNA. Tenofovir inhibits this enzyme ➜ prevents integration into host genome ➜ stops replication.

Hepatitis B Virus is a partially double-stranded DNA virus that also uses a reverse transcription step during replication of its relaxed circular DNA. Tenofovir inhibits HBV DNA polymerase, which also has reverse transcriptase activity.This leads to suppression of HBV replication.

questions.text: A 38 -year-old man is newly diagnosed with HIV. He is asymptomatic with a CD4 count of 650 cells/mm³. Based on WHO recommendations, which of the following combinations would be best suited for treatment of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir

Explanation:

  • Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir is a recommended first-line regimen for the treatment of HIV.
  • This combination includes three drugs from two different classes: Tenofovir and Lamivudine, which provide a backbone of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), and Dolutegravir, a potent integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI) known for its strong efficacy.
  • Dolutegravir-based therapy is available in fixed-dose combinations, which simplifies treatment regimens, reduces costs, and enhances adherence to therapy.
  • This combination is widely accepted among various patient populations, including those living with HIV, individuals with HIV/TB co-infections, and adolescents, due to its effectiveness and tolerability.

 

Zidovudine + Lamivudine + Raltegravir (Option A) is the first line regimen for HIV-positive neonates as this combination has shown effectiveness in rapidly suppressing viral load in infants and neonates.

 

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Lopinavir (Option B) is generally not used as the first-line therapy for HIV infection. Moreover, Abacavir requires HLA-B*5701 testing due to the risk of hypersensitivity reactions, which can be severe and potentially life-threatening.

 

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz (Option C) was previously recommended as the first-line therapy for HIV. However, according to the 2018 recommendations, efavirenz was replaced by Dolutegravir.

questions.text: A 55-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with fever, cough, and respiratory distress. CT  chest is perfomed. Which of the following investigations would be most specific to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Lung histology shows fungal septate hyphae with branching at 45 degrees

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Galactomannan antigen test from respiratory samples

 

Explanation:

  • HRCT chest in immunocompromised patient shows air crescent sign (right lung)  and Halo sign  (posterior segment of the left lower lobe, abutting the vertebral body) seen in Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.
  • Galactomannan antigen test on BAL is a sensitive and specific biomarker for diagnosing invasive aspergillosis.It detects a polysaccharide component of the Aspergillus cell wall that is released during active infection.
  • Beta-1,3-D-glucan is more panfungal, so it's helpful in screening but less specific.
  • The BACTEC™ MGIT 960 system is an automated, rapid culture system used primarily for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and other mycobacteria from clinical specimens. 
  • Histological examination in invasive aspergillosis reveals hyphae, which are hyaline, narrow, septate, and branch at 45°. It is diagnostic in only 10-30% cases

questions.text: AIDS Patient is having CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm. He is having fever, cough and shortness of breath for past one week. Auscultation reveals scattered bronchial breathing in left infra-axillary and infrascapular areas. CXR reveals air bronchograms in left lower lobe. Which oppurtunisitc infection is present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A : Pneumococcus 

Explanation: 

Though it looks as if answer should be pneumocystis jiroveci based on CD4 count, but auscultation findings and CXR findings indicate lobar pneumonia. Hence the answer is pneumococccus. In fact the most common lung infection in AIDS patients overall is bacterial pneumonia. 

Features that must be given in Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia case 

CD4 <200 cells/μL plus 

  1. Bilateral interstitial or perihilar infiltrates

  2. Gradual onset of dry cough, hypoxia, and no focal findings on auscultation

  3. Often normal chest auscultation early on and later occassional crepitations in both lung fields

questions.text: Truck driver with AIDS is brought  in with fever and altered mental status. His family  reports a week-long history of worsening headache, fever, projectile vomiting, and confusion. Neuroimaging shows soaps bubble appearance and CSF shows 50 lymphoctes/cu.mm  with low sugar and mild increase of protein. Which of the following is most accurate test for confirmation of diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A: CSF Lateral flow asssay

 

Explanation:

The patient has signs and symptoms of meningitis which along with soap bubble appearance on the brain MRI led to the diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis. The best test for diagnosis is CSF lateral flow assay that can be performed on blood sample / CSF sample of this patient. The diagnostic accuracy of mucicarmine staining and india ink stain is lesser.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant born to an HIV-positive mother is brought to OPD. The baby was delivered vaginally and was not breastfed. The mother has been on antiretroviral therapy throughout pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to diagnose HIV infection in this neonate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) PCR HIV DNA

 

Explanation:

  • In infants <18 months, maternal IgG antibodies cross the placenta and persist, making antibody-based tests (like ELISA) unreliable.

  • HIV DNA PCR detects proviral DNA integrated into the infant’s CD4+ T-cells — it's the most sensitive and specific test for early infant diagnosis.

  • HIV RNA PCR is also useful but less preferred in newborns due to variable viremia and higher false positives.

  • p24 antigen and 4th gen ELISA are not accurate in neonates due to antibody interference and lower sensitivity.

questions.text: A 28-year-old lab technician presents 10 days after sustaining a needle-stick injury while drawing blood from an HIV-positive patient. He did not receive post-exposure prophylaxis  He is currently asymptomatic and anxious about possible seroconversion. Which of the following test will help in early detection of possible transmission of infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HIV PCR RNA 

 

Explanation:

  • HIV RNA PCR detects viral RNA in plasma as early as 10–14 days post-exposure, making it the earliest marker of infection. In high-risk exposures like this, HIV RNA PCR is the test of choice for early detection when PEP was not initiated. The simple logic is that PCR is capable of detecting infection before antigen or antibody formation.

  • HIV DNA PCR is  used for neonatal diagnosis.

  • p24 antigen appears after RNA but before antibodies, and is included in 4th gen ELISA. p24 antigen turns positive by day 15 onwards 

  • 4th generation ELISA (Ab + p24) is excellent for screening but may still miss very early infection as it turns positive on day 23 onwards

questions.text: Which is correct about definiton of AIDS?

choices.text: ELISA positive for HIV plus any WHO clinical stage 4 condition that includes AIDS-defining illnesses
ELISA positive for HIV plus CD4 count less than 350 cells /cu.mm
ELISA positive for HIV plus CD4 count less than 500 cells /cu.mm
ELISA positive for HIV plus persistent generalized lymphadenopathy involving > 2 groups

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ELISA positive for HIV plus any WHO clinical stage 4 condition that includes AIDS-defining illnesses

 

Explanation:

According to the World Health Organization (WHO):

AIDS is diagnosed in an HIV-positive individual when they have either:

  1. A CD4+ T-cell count <200 cells/μL,
    OR

  2. Any WHO clinical stage 4 condition, which includes AIDS-defining illnesses (e.g., Pneumocystis pneumonia, cryptococcal meningitis, Kaposi sarcoma, esophageal candidiasis, etc.)

questions.text: A 53-year-old man visits the clinic with recurring respiratory infections and oral candidiasis. Lab tests show a CD4 count of 150 cells/mm³, raising suspicion for HIV. Which structure allows the HIV virus to attach to CD4 cells initially?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) gp120

 

 

Explanation:

 

  • The gp120 glycoprotein on the surface of HIV binds specifically to the CD4 receptor on T cells, which is important for the virus to attach and enter the host cell while gp41 is the transmembrane glycoprotein (mediates membrane fusion) to which the virus will bind. 

  • CCR5 is the primary coreceptor used by HIV-1 during initial infection and transmission. It is expressed on macrophages, dendritic cells, and memory T cells.

  • CCR5 binds to the viral envelope glycoprotein (gp120) after it has bound to CD4, facilitating fusion and entry of the virus into the host cell.

  • p24: capsid protein abd p17: matrix protein

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman diagnosed with HIV is in her third trimester of pregnancy. Which of the following statements is not true regarding vertical transmission of HIV?

choices.text: ART greatly lowers the risk of vertical transmission.
Transmission can occur through breast milk.
Prolonged membrane rupture increases transmission risk.
Viral transmission does not occur in the first trimester.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Viral transmission does not occur in the first trimester.

 

Explanation:

 

  • HIV transmission can happen from the affected mother to the child from the first trimester of pregnancy, during delivery and breastfeeding. (Option B)
  • Prolonged labour, After PROM, the amniotic sac is no longer intact, and the baby is directly exposed to maternal vaginal and cervical secretions, which may contain high levels of HIV.(Option C)
  • ART has greatly reduced the risk of transmission in recent times, combined with cesarean delivery, which has made mother-to-child transmission of HIV extremely low. (Option A)

 

Routes of Transmission of HIV

Sexual contact
  • Receptive and insertive anal intercourse
  • Receptive and insertive penile-vaginal intercourse
  • Oral intercourse

Parenteral route
  • Blood transfusion
  • Needle-sharing (IV drugs)
  • Occupational exposure (e.g., needle stick injuries)

Vertical transmission
  • Mother to child (the best test for identifying vertical transmission is HIV PCR DNA).

 

 

Types of HIV

HIV 1
  • This is the most common and widespread type of HIV
  • Comparatively, this type progresses more rapidly to AIDS (10 years)
  • HIV-1 group M commonly causes the AIDS pandemic, and its subtype C is common in India.

HIV 2
  • This type is less common and mainly found in Africa
  • Progression to AIDS is usually in 15 - 20 years

questions.text: A 30-year-old asthmatic patient presents with worsening respiratory symptoms and is diagnosed with Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis . Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment strategy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Itraconazole combined with low-dose corticosteroids

 

Explanation:

The most appropriate initial treatment strategy for an asthmatic patient diagnosed with ABPA is Itraconazole combined with low-dose corticosteroids. Steroids are given as this disease is a hypersensitivity reaction to colonization of airways with aspergillus fumigatus. In contrast invasive pulmonary aspergilloma is treated with voriconazole. 

Invasive Pulmonary Aspergilloma occurs in immunocompromised hosts (e.g. neutropenic, transplant, prolonged steroids). It is a tissue-invasive infection and  not a hypersensitivity.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not seen with allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis?

choices.text: Presence of hyper-attenuated mucus on imaging

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Halo sign on HRCT chest

 

Explanation: 

Halo sign is seen with invasive pulmonary aspergilloma while the question is on ABPA. Both are different diseases with ABPA being hypersensitivty to aspergillus fumigatus and characterised by central bronchiectasis. 

 

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA) is a hypersensitivity reaction to germinating fungal spores in the airway, primarily affecting individuals with asthma and cystic fibrosis. 

  • Symptoms:
    • Patients typically experience bronchial obstruction due to mucus plugs, leading to coughing fits, pneumonia-like symptoms, consolidation, and breathlessness.
    • Expectorating thick, often brown sputum casts.
    • Fever and breathlessness and worsening asthma symptoms.
  • Diagnosis:
  1. Elevated specific and total serum IgE levels (>1000 IU/mL) (Option A ruled out)
  2. Positive skin-prick test
  3. Imaging:
    • Presence of hyper-attenuated mucus in airways is highly specific (Option C ruled out)
    • Proximal /Central  Bronchiectasis is characteristic
    • It may mimic pneumonia due to infiltrates
    • Segmental or lobar collapse on chest X-rays, especially in stable asthma cases
    • Tram track appearance in CT d/t bronchiectasis
    • X-ray:
      • Cylindrical & proximal bronchiectasis with thickening of the bronchial wall (Tree in bud appearance)
      • Mucous impaction in dilated bronchi (Finger-in-glove appearance)
      • HRCT: Central bronchiectasis (Option B ruled out) and bronchial wall thickening with atelectatic areas.
